metadata.title: Status Epilepticus with Hypoglycemia
learning_objectives: ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients
Identify hypoglycemia as treatable cause of seizures
Manage airway during active seizure safely
Demonstrate critical thinking: treat causes not just symptoms

changelog.v3.0_enhanced: Blueprint Structure Enhancement v2 applied: matching config, clinical anchors, consequence templates, ECG standardization. Deterioration timing 5/9/13 min. Duration 20 minutes. Removed challenge_points.

dispatch_info.additional_info: Shaking all over, been going on for several minutes, can't wake her up

scene_description.location: Bedroom, patient on floor next to bed
scene_description.safety: Scene safe, boyfriend moved furniture away from patient
scene_description.access: 2nd floor, narrow staircase, boyfriend can help with carry
scene_description.bystanders: Boyfriend present, very distressed but trying to help, knows patient's history

patient_profile.name: Andrea
patient_profile.personality: During seizure: unresponsive. Post-ictal: confused, gradually recovers, anxious about what happened

initial.student_sees: You arrive to find a young woman lying on her side on the bedroom floor, actively seizing. Her whole body is rigid, then shaking rhythmically - arms and legs jerking violently. Her eyes are rolled back, jaw clenched tight. You can hear a gurgling sound from her airway and see saliva pooling at the corner of her mouth. Her lips have a bluish tinge. The boyfriend is kneeling beside her, crying. 'She's been like this for at least 6 or 7 minutes now! I called as soon as it started. She has epilepsy but her seizures usually stop after a minute or two. This one won't stop!' You can smell urine - she's incontinent. On the nightstand you notice an insulin pen and a glucose meter.
initial.appearance: Young female, actively seizing (tonic-clonic), cyanotic lips, incontinent, jaw clenched, secretions pooling
initial.clinical_note: STATUS EPILEPTICUS (seizure >5 minutes). CRITICAL FINDING: Patient is Type 1 diabetic (insulin pen visible). Boyfriend mentions she didn't eat yesterday. HIGH PROBABILITY OF HYPOGLYCEMIA as CAUSE of seizure. Must check glucose IMMEDIATELY. Hypoglycemic seizure responds to GLUCOSE, not benzodiazepine. Check glucose before giving diazepam.

improving.student_sees: The seizure has stopped. The patient is lying still now, breathing more regularly though still fast. She's not yet responsive to your voice - when you call her name, she just groans. Her color is improving - lips less blue. She's in the postictal phase. After a few more minutes, her eyes flutter open. 'Wha... what happened? Where am I?' she asks in a confused, slurred voice. The boyfriend is crying with relief. 'Oh thank God, Andrea, you're okay!'
improving.appearance: Postictal - confused, groaning, slowly becoming more alert, color improving
improving.clinical_note: Seizure terminated (either from glucose correcting hypoglycemia, or from benzodiazepine). Postictal phase is normal - patient will gradually become more alert over 10-20 minutes. Continue monitoring glucose, watch for recurrence, supportive care.

deteriorating.student_sees: The seizure continues despite your interventions - or has restarted after briefly stopping. She's seizing violently, and her oxygen level keeps dropping. Her lips and fingertips are now deeply blue. The seizure activity is becoming less organized - more twitching than rhythmic shaking - but she's still not responsive. Her breathing between the convulsions is shallow and inadequate.
deteriorating.appearance: Ongoing or recurrent seizure, severe hypoxia, cyanotic, secretions, inadequate breathing
deteriorating.clinical_note: Ongoing status epilepticus with respiratory compromise. If glucose not corrected, seizure will continue. If benzodiazepine given without glucose, may have some effect but underlying cause not treated. Prepare for respiratory support with BVM.

critical.student_sees: CRITICAL: The patient's seizure has stopped but not because she's better - because she's exhausted. She's now unresponsive and barely breathing. Her lips are blue-gray. Her breathing is slow and shallow - maybe 6 breaths per minute. She doesn't respond to anything. This is respiratory failure from prolonged seizure and/or medication-induced respiratory depression.
critical.appearance: Unresponsive, agonal breathing, cyanotic, no seizure activity (exhaustion or suppression)
critical.clinical_note: Respiratory failure - either from seizure exhaustion or benzodiazepine-induced respiratory depression. Requires immediate BVM ventilation. If glucose still low, ongoing hypoglycemic brain injury. This is pre-arrest state.

airway.during_seizure: AT RISK - jaw clenched, secretions pooling, cannot insert OPA during active seizure
airway.post_ictal: May need OPA if not protecting airway

breathing.during_seizure: Irregular, often breath-holding during tonic phase, rapid during clonic phase, SpO2 falling
breathing.post_ictal: Regular but may be depressed, especially if benzodiazepine given

circulation.during_seizure: HR 135, BP 155/92 (elevated from seizure activity), peripheral perfusion adequate

disability.during_seizure: GCS 3 (E1V1M1) - but this is during convulsion, not true baseline
disability.post_ictal: GCS 6-8 initially, gradually improving to 10-12, then 14-15 over 20 minutes

exposure.during_seizure: Incontinent of urine (common), check for tongue bite (common), check for injuries from fall
exposure.environment: Bedroom - insulin pen and glucose meter on nightstand - CRITICAL CLUE

sample_history.symptoms: Generalized tonic-clonic seizure ongoing 6-7 minutes when EMS arrived
medications: Insulin: Novorapid (rapid) with meals, Lantus (long-acting) at bedtime
CRITICAL INFO from boyfriend: 'She had stomach bug yesterday, didn't eat much, but I think she still took her insulin last night'
sample_history.past_history: Epilepsy for 5 years (usually controlled), Type 1 Diabetes for 12 years
sample_history.last_intake: Boyfriend: 'She barely ate yesterday because she was sick. Just some crackers.'
sample_history.events: Woke up this morning feeling 'shaky and weak' (HYPOGLYCEMIA WARNING SIGNS). Then started seizing about 7-8 minutes ago.

critical_clues.reduced_food_intake: Didn't eat yesterday due to illness
critical_clues.insulin_taken: Probably still took her insulin despite not eating
critical_clues.morning_symptoms: 'Shaky and weak' this morning = hypoglycemia prodrome
critical_clues.glucose_meter_visible: On nightstand - patient monitors her glucose regularly

interpretation.diagnosis: Sinus tachycardia - catecholamine response to seizure
interpretation.mechanism: Sympathetic surge from seizure activity and hypoglycemia

ecg_findings.teaching_point: ECG during seizure will have artifact. Tachycardia is expected (catecholamine surge). ECG is NOT a priority - glucose check and seizure termination are priorities. Post-seizure ECG useful to rule out arrhythmia as seizure cause (cardiac syncope misdiagnosed as seizure).

glucose_40_percent.mechanism: Directly provides glucose for brain metabolism

dosing.administration: Slow IV push, flush with saline after
dosing.repeat: Recheck glucose in 5 minutes, repeat if <4.0

scenario_specific_response.patient_response: Seizure terminates. Patient enters postictal phase, gradually wakes up over 10-15 minutes. 'What happened? Did I have a seizure?'
scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: TREATS THE CAUSE. Glucose corrects hypoglycemia which was causing seizure. Seizure stops because brain metabolism is restored.
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: GLUCOSE TREATS THE CAUSE. Benzodiazepine suppresses the symptom. Always check glucose in seizures and give glucose if low BEFORE benzodiazepine.

diazepam.mechanism: Enhances GABA inhibition, raises seizure threshold

dosing.repeat: May repeat 10mg after 5-10 minutes if seizure continues (max 20mg prehospital)

warnings: Monitor respiratory rate - have BVM ready
In hypoglycemic seizure, benzo may stop seizure but doesn't fix cause - seizure may recur
Max 20mg prehospital to avoid respiratory depression

without_glucose_first.patient_response: Seizure may stop but patient remains deeply unconscious (hypoglycemia + sedation). May re-seize when benzo wears off because glucose still low.
without_glucose_first.clinical_effect: Suppresses seizure but doesn't treat cause. Patient at high risk of re-seizure and respiratory depression.

with_glucose_first.clinical_effect: If glucose given first and seizure stopped, benzo may not be needed. If seizure continues despite glucose correction, benzo is appropriate backup.
with_glucose_first.teaching_point: Benzodiazepine is backup, not first-line, in hypoglycemic seizure.

scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Apply oxygen during seizure. Patient is hypoxic from breath-holding and secretions. Oxygen helps but doesn't stop seizure.

scenario_specific_response.clinical_effect: Will eventually raise glucose but much slower than IV glucose
scenario_specific_response.teaching_point: Glucagon is backup for hypoglycemia when IV access impossible. Works by mobilizing liver glycogen - slower than IV glucose.

glucose.patient_says: Initially nothing (postictal). Then gradually: 'What... what happened?'
glucose.clinical_effect: Seizure terminates because CAUSE (hypoglycemia) is treated

diazepam_alone.clinical_effect: Suppresses seizure but underlying hypoglycemia persists - high risk of recurrence

5min.description: Ongoing seizure, hypoxia worsening, glucose dropping further, secretions accumulating

9min.description: Status epilepticus continues, severe hypoxia, profound hypoglycemia, brain damage accumulating

13min.description: Seizure may be stopping from exhaustion, respiratory failure, bradycardia from hypoxia, near-arrest

critical_harm.name: insulin
critical_harm.why_dangerous: Patient is HYPO-glycemic - insulin would be catastrophic

if_given.patient_response: CRITICAL ERROR: Patient is hypoglycemic, you've given insulin which drops glucose further. Seizure intensifies, patient at severe risk of death.

critical_harm.teaching_point: ALWAYS check glucose before giving insulin. Diabetics can be HYPER or HYPO glycemic - they are opposite conditions requiring opposite treatments.

critical_harm.name: excessive_benzodiazepine

if_given.patient_response: Patient stops breathing. Seizure stops too - but from respiratory depression, not from successful treatment.

critical_harm.teaching_point: Max 20mg diazepam prehospital. More = respiratory arrest. Have BVM ready with any benzodiazepine use.

worsens.name: oral_airway_during_seizure
worsens.why_wrong: Causes injury - teeth break, jaw injury, finger injury

if_attempted.clinical_effect: Cannot insert - jaw clenched with tremendous force. Risk of broken teeth, injury to provider.

worsens.teaching_point: NEVER force anything into a seizing patient's mouth. Wait until seizure stops. Position on side, suction accessible secretions, apply oxygen near face.

neutral.name: phenytoin

if_given.clinical_effect: Appropriate second-line if benzodiazepine fails and underlying cause treated. Takes 20+ minutes to work.

neutral.teaching_point: Phenytoin is second-line for status epilepticus. Requires slow IV infusion, cardiac monitoring. Usually hospital therapy.

critical_failures.description: Glucose never checked in seizing diabetic patient
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Hypoglycemic seizure continues untreated. Patient develops permanent neurological damage from prolonged neuroglycopenia. Simple, reversible cause missed - patient suffers brain injury from preventable hypoglycemia.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Checking blood glucose is MANDATORY in ALL seizure patients, especially those with diabetes history. Hypoglycemia is the most easily reversible cause of seizures. It takes 15 seconds to check and 2 minutes to fix with IV glucose. Failure to check means you miss the one thing you can instantly cure. This patient seized from low blood sugar - give glucose and seizure stops immediately. Without checking, you're treating blind and missing the reversible cause.

critical_failures.description: Benzodiazepine given WITHOUT checking glucose first
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Seizure suppressed by benzodiazepine but underlying hypoglycemia untreated. Patient remains unconscious from low blood sugar (now masked by sedation). Brain continues to starve for glucose. Permanent neurological damage from prolonged hypoglycemia.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: NEVER give benzodiazepine before checking glucose in seizures. Benzodiazepine suppresses the SYMPTOM (seizure) but doesn't treat the CAUSE. If the cause is hypoglycemia, you've just masked it with sedation while the brain continues to starve. This is a critical sequence error: (1) Check glucose FIRST, (2) Give glucose if low, (3) THEN give benzodiazepine if seizure continues. Always treat the cause before suppressing symptoms.

critical_failures.description: Excessive benzodiazepine dose (>20mg diazepam) causing respiratory arrest
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Respiratory depression progresses to apnea. Patient stops breathing - yes, seizure stops too, but from respiratory arrest, not successful treatment. Iatrogenic respiratory failure.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Maximum 20mg diazepam (or equivalent) in prehospital setting. Higher doses cause respiratory arrest - you stop the seizure by stopping breathing, which is not therapeutic success. Always have BVM ready when giving benzodiazepines, and never exceed dosing limits. If 20mg hasn't worked, patient needs hospital anticonvulsant therapy (phenytoin, levetiracetam), not more benzodiazepine.

critical_failures.description: Forced oral airway insertion during active seizure
critical_failures.patient_outcome: Broken teeth, oral trauma, jaw injury, potential aspiration of tooth fragments. Provider finger injury from bite force. Worsens situation without benefit.
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: NEVER force anything into the mouth of a seizing patient. The jaw is clenched with tremendous force - you will break teeth, injure the jaw, or get bitten. It provides no benefit and causes harm. Correct airway management during seizure: position on side, suction accessible secretions, apply oxygen near face. Wait until seizure terminates before inserting airways.

critical_failures.patient_outcome: Allergic reaction on top of existing seizure emergency
critical_failures.aar_teaching_point: Always verify allergies before medication administration.

initial.description: Active generalized tonic-clonic seizure - patient convulsing, unresponsive, hypoxic (SpO2 84%), known diabetic with blood glucose 2.1 mmol/L (critically low). Seizure from hypoglycemia.

early_deteriorating.description: Continued seizure activity, worsening hypoxia, prolonged neuroglycopenia causing progressive brain damage

deteriorating.description: Status epilepticus established (>5 min continuous seizure), severe hypoxia, brain injury accumulating from prolonged hypoglycemia and seizure

critical.description: Refractory status epilepticus, respiratory failure, severe brain injury from prolonged neuroglycopenia, approaching irreversible neurological damage

improving.description: Seizure terminating or terminated after glucose given, consciousness returning, blood sugar normalizing. Dramatic improvement from treating reversible cause.

stable.description: Post-ictal state or full recovery, glucose normalized, breathing adequate, airway protected

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: Recovery position, clear secretions, do NOT force OPA
MUST check glucose in ALL seizure patients, especially known diabetics

exemplary.outcome_description: Glucose checked immediately, identified reversible cause before any medication
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent clinical reasoning - you checked blood glucose IMMEDIATELY and discovered the cause: 2.1 mmol/L (critically low). This single assessment identified the reversible, curable cause of the seizure. You correctly prioritized finding the cause before treating symptoms. This is expert-level seizure management - many providers jump to benzodiazepines without checking the one thing that can be instantly fixed.

competent.outcome_description: Glucose checked before administering benzodiazepine, identified hypoglycemia
competent.feedback_template: Good clinical approach. You checked glucose before giving benzodiazepines and identified the hypoglycemia. This sequence (assess cause → treat cause → symptom management if needed) is correct.

developing.outcome_description: Glucose check delayed significantly, brain exposed to prolonged neuroglycopenia
developing.feedback_template: Blood glucose check was delayed until {patient_state_at_action} state. During that delay, the brain was deprived of glucose for several minutes - this causes cumulative neurological damage. Hypoglycemia is THE most easily reversible cause of seizures. It takes 15 seconds to check. Every minute of delay is a minute of preventable brain injury. What was your clinical reasoning for the delay?

criteria: Didn't recognize need to check glucose in diabetic seizure patient
novice.outcome_description: Critical reversible cause missed or sequence error
novice.feedback_template: This is addressed as a Safety Gate issue - checking blood glucose is MANDATORY in ALL seizure patients. Hypoglycemia is instantly reversible with IV glucose. Without checking, you miss the one cause you can cure in 2 minutes.

exemplary.outcome_description: Glucose given immediately after identifying hypoglycemia, seizure terminated, dramatic recovery
exemplary.feedback_template: Excellent - you gave IV glucose immediately after discovering blood sugar of 2.1 mmol/L. The seizure terminated within 1-2 minutes. This is textbook management of hypoglycemic seizure: check glucose → find it low → give glucose → seizure stops. You treated the CAUSE, not just the symptom. The patient made a dramatic recovery because you addressed the reversible problem. This is one of the most satisfying treatments in emergency medicine - instant cure of a life-threatening condition.

competent.outcome_description: Glucose administered after identifying hypoglycemia, patient improved
competent.feedback_template: Effective treatment. You identified the hypoglycemia and treated it with IV glucose, resolving the seizure. This is correct management of the reversible cause.

developing.outcome_description: Glucose administration delayed despite known hypoglycemia, prolonged brain glucose deprivation
developing.feedback_template: IV glucose was delayed even after identifying blood sugar of 2.1 mmol/L. During that delay, the brain continued to starve for glucose while seizing - this causes cumulative neurological damage. Once you know it's hypoglycemia, glucose administration is URGENT. It's not 'one of the things to do' - it's THE thing to do. What delayed administration after you had the diagnosis?

criteria: Glucose never administered despite hypoglycemia identified
Gave benzodiazepine instead of glucose for hypoglycemic seizure
novice.outcome_description: Reversible cause identified but not treated
novice.feedback_template: This is addressed as Safety Gate and competence issue - once hypoglycemia is identified, IV glucose is the definitive treatment. Benzodiazepines suppress the symptom (seizure) but don't fix the cause (low blood sugar). Without glucose, the brain continues to starve and permanent damage occurs.

critical_actions_checklist.criteria: 10mg diazepam IV if seizure continues AFTER glucose given
Especially after benzodiazepine, have BVM ready

common_errors.teaching_point: ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients - hypoglycemia is reversible cause
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Check glucose, treat the cause. Benzodiazepine suppresses symptoms, glucose fixes the problem.

common_errors.error: Forced oral airway during active seizure
common_errors.teaching_point: NEVER force anything into seizing patient's mouth - risk of injury
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Jaw is clenched with superhuman force during seizure. You will break teeth, not help.

common_errors.teaching_point: Standard adult dose for status epilepticus is 10mg diazepam IV
common_errors.clinical_anchor: 5mg is a half-dose. Status epilepticus needs full treatment - 10mg first, repeat if needed.

common_errors.teaching_point: Max 20mg diazepam prehospital - have BVM ready
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Too much benzo and she stops seizing AND stops breathing. Know your limits.

common_errors.error: Didn't recognize history clues pointing to hypoglycemia
common_errors.teaching_point: Diabetic + didn't eat + took insulin = hypoglycemia setup
common_errors.clinical_anchor: The boyfriend told you everything: diabetic, sick, didn't eat, took insulin. That's hypoglycemia.

common_errors.teaching_point: Recheck glucose and monitor for recurrence
common_errors.clinical_anchor: Glucose can drop again. One dose may not be enough. Monitor and repeat.

consequence_templates.template: Blood glucose was NEVER checked. {patient_name} was a Type 1 diabetic who hadn't eaten and took insulin - the classic hypoglycemia setup. Her seizure was caused by glucose of 1.8 mmol/L. Without checking glucose, you treated the symptom (seizure) but not the cause (hypoglycemia). She remained at risk of ongoing brain damage and recurrent seizures.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Hypoglycemia is a reversible cause of seizures. Failure to check glucose in a known diabetic with seizures is a critical omission. Brain damage from prolonged hypoglycemia is preventable.

consequence_templates.template: Glucose was never given despite documented hypoglycemia (1.8 mmol/L). {patient_name}'s brain was starving for fuel throughout your care. Benzodiazepine may have suppressed the seizure temporarily, but without glucose correction, she remained in metabolic crisis with ongoing neuronal injury.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Hypoglycemic seizures require glucose correction. Benzodiazepine alone is insufficient - the seizure will recur and brain damage continues.

consequence_templates.template: Glucose check was delayed until {actual_time} minutes. {patient_name}'s hypoglycemia (1.8 mmol/L) went undetected during those {delay_minutes} minutes. Each minute of unrecognized hypoglycemia during seizure causes cumulative brain injury.
consequence_templates.medical_basis: Delayed glucose check delays definitive treatment. In hypoglycemic seizure, time to glucose administration directly impacts neurological outcome.

critical_decision_points.description: Checking and treating glucose before giving benzodiazepine
optimal_sequence: Give glucose 40% IV as PRIMARY treatment
Hold benzodiazepine initially - see if glucose alone stops seizure
Give benzodiazepine only if seizure continues AFTER glucose

scoring.optimal: Checked glucose within first minute, recognized hypoglycemia, gave glucose BEFORE benzodiazepine, verbalized reasoning: 'Diabetic who didn't eat - need to check glucose first.'
scoring.acceptable: Checked glucose within 3 minutes, gave glucose, may have given benzodiazepine simultaneously.
scoring.suboptimal: Gave benzodiazepine first, checked glucose later, eventually gave glucose.
scoring.dangerous: Never checked glucose, or gave benzodiazepine repeatedly without ever checking glucose.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Check glucose, treat the cause. Benzodiazepine is backup, glucose is the answer.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients. The boyfriend gave you the diagnosis: Type 1 diabetic who didn't eat but took insulin = hypoglycemia. Glucose TREATS the cause. Benzodiazepine only SUPPRESSES the symptom. In hypoglycemic seizure, glucose stops seizure faster and safer than benzodiazepine.

scoring.optimal: 10mg diazepam IV slowly, waited 5 minutes to assess, had BVM ready, monitored respiratory rate, prepared to repeat if needed.
scoring.suboptimal: Underdosed (5mg) or didn't monitor after giving.
scoring.dangerous: Overdosed (>20mg) causing respiratory depression, or gave without having BVM ready.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: 10mg, wait 5 minutes, watch the breathing, repeat once if needed. No more than 20mg.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Benzodiazepine dosing: 10mg diazepam IV is standard for status epilepticus. Can repeat once after 5-10 minutes (max 20mg prehospital). ALWAYS monitor RR after giving - respiratory depression is the main risk. Have BVM ready before giving any benzodiazepine.

critical_decision_points.description: Safe airway management during active seizure

scoring.optimal: Positioned on side, suctioned accessible secretions, applied oxygen near face, did NOT attempt to insert OPA during active seizure.
scoring.suboptimal: Attempted OPA insertion during seizure but stopped when unsuccessful.
scoring.dangerous: Forced objects into mouth, caused injury.

critical_decision_points.clinical_anchor: Position, suction what you can reach, oxygen nearby. Never force anything into that clenched jaw.
critical_decision_points.aar_teaching_point: Airway management during seizure: Recovery position protects airway and allows secretions to drain. Suction only what you can access without forcing mouth open. Apply oxygen near face. NEVER insert OPA or bite block during active seizure - jaw is clenched with tremendous force. Wait until seizure stops.

key_concepts: ALWAYS check glucose in seizure patients - especially diabetics
Hypoglycemia is reversible cause - glucose treats cause, benzodiazepine treats symptom
Diabetic + didn't eat + took insulin = hypoglycemia until proven otherwise
NEVER force anything into seizing patient's mouth
Benzodiazepine max 20mg prehospital - have BVM ready
clinical_pearls: Postictal confusion is normal - patient will gradually improve over 10-20 minutes
10mg diazepam is standard dose - 5mg is usually inadequate for status epilepticus
If seizure stops with glucose alone, benzodiazepine wasn't needed
Recheck glucose after treatment - may need repeat dosing
